message_1: What is the total volume of gas (in liters) released at standard temperature and pressure (STP) when 10 grams of sulfuric acid (H2SO4) is added to 20 grams of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) in a closed container at 25 degrees Celsius? (Assuming the reaction goes to completion and all gas is collected).
message_2:
The balanced chemical equation for the reaction between sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and calcium carbonate (CaCO3) is:

H2SO4 + CaCO3 â†’ CaSO4 + H2O + CO2

First, we need to determine the limiting reactant. To do this, we'll calculate the moles of each reactant:

Moles of H2SO4 = mass / molar mass = 10 g / (2*1 + 32 + 4*16) g/mol = 10 g / 98 g/mol = 0.102 mol

Moles of CaCO3 = mass / molar mass = 20 g / (40 + 12 + 3*16) g/mol = 20 g / 100 g/mol = 0.200 mol

Now, we'll compare the mole ratio of the reactants to the stoichiometry of the balanced equation:

Mole ratio = moles of H2SO4 / moles of CaCO3 = 0.102 mol / 0.200 mol = 0.51

Since the stoichiometry of the balanced equation is 1:1, H2SO4 is the limiting reactant. Therefore, the amount of CO2 produced will be based on the moles of H2SO4.

At standard temperature and pressure (STP), 1 mole of any gas occupies 22.4 liters. So, the volume of CO2 produced can be calculated as follows:

Volume of CO2 = moles of H2SO4 * 22.4 L/mol = 0.102 mol * 22.4 L/mol = 2.28 L

Thus, the total volume of gas released at STP when 10 grams of H2SO4 is added to 20 grams of CaCO3 in a closed container at 25 degrees Celsius is 2.28 liters.
